Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WhiteLightning I went from 4.5 to < 1.0 after Brachy. A year later I was at < 0.6. Two years it bounced to 0.9. Then settled down to 0.0 and that's where it has remained. I had 116 I-125 seeds on July 25, 2003. It often takes time to settle down. Hi guys, Had brachy on july 10th and the first blood test one month later was 3.2 and then another month later it was 1.1. So far it has been alright. I still have some urinating problems. Good luck wish ful

Posts.Content: Hi Guys, I haven't been on here for quite a while due to not having any issues with Brachytherapy. I would like to give you my experience with this procedure. You can see by my signature where I'm at with PSA, so I'll start with Procedure done on 7/10, 2014. One month after procedure PSA 3.3 and having urgency and leakage and trouble urinating. Changing a pad once a day. On 9/6 PSA 1.1, still some problems with the same symptoms as before. On 12/5 PSA .5 with no symptoms for the last couple of months. Never any ED problems after the first couple of months. I know of one person who had brachytherapy about 12 years ago without any problems. I would like to start a thread to ask for people who have had brachytherapy at least 5 years ago to share there experience? I see a lot of people on here who had surgery and still talking about it years later. I would like to know if they have ED problems I went to Emory University for my treatment and the chairman of the urology department recommended brachytherapy. So I went with it. Not all people are a candidate for this procedure. Well. I wish the best for anyone who has Prostate Cancer

Sometimes, I feel that I created this with the drinking I've done during my life. Also, since no one in my family was a drinker. I'm not talking about heavy drinking every day but I'm the person that liked a couple of beers when I got home from work. I give this up 5 years ago and would only drink on occasion. I gave up drinking completely a year ago. Anyone fell this way? When you mentioned about John Wayne it got me thinking. Sorry about off the subject, didn't mean to.
Posts.Title: After PC do you find other tests more stressful?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the information. I really appreciate it. It definitely help me to make the best out of it. I'll know on Monday about what is going on.
Posts.Title: MRI need help on results

Posts.Content: Hi guys, I know that I should not be starting another post but I need some help fast. People on here say to get a surgeon with a 1000 plus surgeries under their belt. That is not easy to do. I've been working on this for days. They want you to make an appointment that will be sometime in July since I'm a new patient. I ask if they can tell me how many surgeries they've done. No can do. Come in for your appointment in July and they can talk to you about it. If you can give me a name of someone you've dealt with who has this many I would appreciate it. I rather take a chance with that then do what I'm doing. Thanks in advance
Posts.Title: Need help with finding a surgeon with 1000 surgeried

Posts.Content: I had an MRI with out contrast and with it. I wish I could of had one with a rectal coil but not offered in my area. Could someone give me there opinion on these results? Rounded area of T2 signal hypointensity within the left central zone with dimensions as above with adjacent focus of T2 signal hypointensity measuring 1.4cm X 0.7 X 1.5 cm extending into the left base peripheral zone adjacent to the bladder. There is no corresponding restriction of diffusion or rapid contrast washout. Findings suggest possible carcinoma in this area of the peripheral zone with one out of three positive parametric findings placing probability at approx. 50%. There is no evidence for extracapsular extension or regional metastatic disease. I don't understand the one out of three positive parametric findings. I've looked on the internet and can't understand the explanation. Any help would be appreciated. Waiting for biopsy which could take more than week. The periprostatice fat is preserved with no evidence for extracapsular tumor extension. The seminal vesicles are normal in appearance. NO pelvic lymphadenopathy is identified. No aggressive bony lesions identified in the visualized portions of the pelvis. The bladder is unremarkable. Thanks

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla wishful, you should really consolidate all your posts to some degree and put your info in your signature in order to make it easier for folks to reply. Unfortunately, you have joined our club. Your biopsy appears to say you have Gleason 7 (3+4) with three cores positive with a max involvement of a core of 20%. The "High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia" or HGPIN looks like another read on that core or another from that area. It means they found tissue that may be a precursor to cancer, but cannot be called cancer. It does not mean that the cancer they found on the apex is "high grade"... your Gleason score is what is important. By NCCN guidelines you are Intermediate Risk. I would suggest that you have your slides sent out for a 2nd opinion to validate the scores. In some cases the scores are changed... and if changed down, then AS would be an option. Regardless, if the score remains 3+4, you are still in an excellent position for successful treatment (or even AS dependent on your age). What did your urologist recommend? Still no need to panic, you have time to think through this and what you want to do. Best of luck and keep us updated. Hi Mikla, I'm not sure on what you mean about consolidating my posts. Can you explain? that to me

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by malbaby Hi wish full. The following is my own personal opinion. Your particular situation obviously depends on what stage your cancer is at. There are a lot more people on this forum with greater knowledge than me. Once I had decided on having treatment....the choice is between surgery and bracchytheraphy, I chose bracchy because it is less invasive and the risks of complications are less. Post bracchy I have experienced urgency, frequency, dysuria and poor stream. I currently take Flomax which helps with alleviating the problems. I often think, did I make the right decision in having treatment, but then I think that I could be much worse off if I ended up with cancer spreading to other areas of my body. The question to ask yourself and your doctor is....what are the consequences in not having any treatment versus lifestyle post treatment. Hi malbaby, I understand your concern. What it really weird I have these problems right now after having a saturation biopsy. It's been now about two weeks. It seems like it came from the catheter. I'm going to ask my Doctor about that and see what he says How long ago did you have treatment? Good luck.
Posts.Title: Brachytherrapy any advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobertG Like you, I had a recommendation from my urologist which I appreciated. We are very similar people - younger (50s) and still very active in sports. He said if it were him, he'd choose brachytherapy partly because of the incontinence issues with surgery which are difficult to deal with in high impact sports like running. I then had a doctor friend of mine do a little research for me and he made the same recommendation. He said that it was clear that the results for brachytherapy are getting better and better over the years, so it is important to look at newer data. My own research supported this, some of the internet searches came up with stuff from the 90s or early 2000s which heavily leaned towards surgery, but if you look at data in the last 10 years or so brachytherapy looks like a very solid option. I would be concerned about the doctor saying that surgery is an option after brachytherapy. My understanding is that it is much riskier than surgery without radiation and not often done. I made my choice on the assumption that it would not be a likely salvage option. Thanks for the reply. I feel that it should be the same. I go on Thursday for consultation and will let you know.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mikla wishful, you should really consolidate all your posts to some degree and put your info in your signature in order to make it easier for folks to reply. Unfortunately, you have joined our club. Your biopsy appears to say you have Gleason 7 (3+4) with three cores positive with a max involvement of a core of 20%. The "High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia" or HGPIN looks like another read on that core or another from that area. It means they found tissue that may be a precursor to cancer, but cannot be called cancer. It does not mean that the cancer they found on the apex is "high grade"... your Gleason score is what is important. By NCCN guidelines you are Intermediate Risk. I would suggest that you have your slides sent out for a 2nd opinion to validate the scores. In some cases the scores are changed... and if changed down, then AS would be an option. Regardless, if the score remains 3+4, you are still in an excellent position for successful treatment (or even AS dependent on your age). What did your urologist recommend? Posts.Content: Hi Everyone, After going to Emory and talking to Dr Martin Sanda Chairmen of the Urology department I have also decided to go with the brachytherapy treatment like what Robert is doing. Robert, I sent you a Private Message and hope to keep in contact with you. I asked Dr Sanda what he would do with all of his knowledge about Prostate cancer. He said if I were you and with all the information that you have given me I would go with the brachytherapy. I asked Dr. Sands if there was a problem could I go back and have the Prostate taken out and he said, no problem. He said with my MRI and a biopsy of 40 cores there should be no surprises. Anybody else out there have any advise on this? I still have not called my decision in.
Posts.Title: Brachytherrapy any advice

Posts.Content: Just returned from the oncologist and he said that there are two treatments for Brachytherapy One is the LDR which puts the seeds in the prostate and leaves them there. On this procedure you have about a four month side affect of urinating very frequently and usually it's urgent. On the second procedure HDR you put the radiation in and then take it out. You have to have two treatments. On this procedure you don't have any side effects. He said they both have the same results. Any opinions or ideas about which worked the best? Thanks in advance Wish full
